scheme.title: Initial closed form expression for each digit
scheme.desc: Uses the base-2n representation of $n^k$ to find a closed form expression of each digit $a_i=\left\lfloor \frac{n^k}{(2n)^i}\right\rfloor mod\ (2n)$

scheme.title: Interchanging the floor and mod
scheme.desc: Transforms the digit expression into a easily boundable one by interchanging the floor and modulo operations.

scheme.title: Bounding the expression
scheme.desc: Correctly bounds the aforementioned expression, usually by showing the numerator is divisible by n, so that $a_i>=\left\lfloor \frac{n}{2^i}\right\rfloor$\|.$

scheme.title: Finishing
scheme.desc: Chooses a provably sufficiently large $N$. The point is not awarded if it has not proven that n^k has at most k digits.

scheme.title: Pigeonhole principle
scheme.desc: Identifies 2 polynomials which share a coefficient of 0 at the same power of $x$.

scheme.title: Adjacent zero coefficients
scheme.desc: Finds a divisor polynomial that has 2 adjacent zero coefficients.

scheme.title: Root distinctness contradiction
scheme.desc: Shows that a divisor polynomial with adjacent zero coefficients cannot have distinct real roots.

scheme.title: Finishing
scheme.desc: Combines everything into a cohesive and correct solution (all the separate concepts, or the entire solutions must be correct).

scheme.title: Connectivity of construction
scheme.desc: The given construction is correct and induces a graph that is connected.

scheme.title: Finiteness of shortest paths
scheme.desc: The given construction induces a graph where the shortest path between any two nodes is finite.

scheme.title: Showing the graph is planar
scheme.desc: The given construction is correct and induces a planar graph.

scheme.title: Finishing
scheme.desc: Combining planarity and finite connectivity to show that the construction is a winning strategy for Alice.

scheme.title: Additional construction
scheme.desc: Constructs useful points. Is only granted if the given construction gives you useful properties that can be used to reach the solution.

scheme.title: Properties of the construction
scheme.desc: Proves useful properties of the construction that involves some symmetry along the $(AFP)$ circle. Points are granted based on the progress made.

scheme.title: Finishing
scheme.desc: Shows that $CX=CY$ by utilising the aforementioned properties

scheme.title: Reduction to powers of prime divisors of n+1
scheme.desc: Uses Chinese Remainder Theorem to reduce the problem to a system of equations modulo $p_l^{e_l}$.

scheme.title: Remainder of $\frac{n-j}{j} when p_l does not divide j
scheme.desc: Represents the term $n \choose i$ as a product of fractions $\frac{n-j}{j}$ and finds the remainder of the terms $\frac{n-l}{l}^k$ where $p_l$ does not divide $j$.

scheme.title: Remainder of $\frac{n-j}{j} when $p_l$ divides $j$
scheme.desc: Represents the term $n \choose i$ as a product of fractions $\frac{n-j}{j}$ and finds the remainder of the terms $\frac{n-l}{l}^k$ where $p_l$ divides $j$.

scheme.title: Defining a graph
scheme.desc: Redefine the problem as a graph matching problem using a viable reformulation.

scheme.title: Hall's theorem
scheme.desc: Apply the converse of Hall's theorem as many times as possible until you reach a set that has a perfect matching

scheme.title: Reducing the problem
scheme.desc: Show that by applying the matching of the final set you can reduce the problem by 1 person.
